Doctor, will he die?

Right, let him through.
Ah, an educated man, you see? Thank you, Captain. Hey, what are you doing up at the pit? Going to blow it up, are you?
How did you know that?
Well, I've got eyes, haven't I.
Yes, you have. And now perhaps you will be good enough to be on your way.
Such courtesy. Thank you, Captain.
(sotto) Blast.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jones examines a specimen under a microscope.

Look, I'm sorry, I know I'm a cloth-head, but

Yes, but I don't understand.
Well, it's quite simple, Jo. We're putting some of the green cells from the maggot's trail with some human body cells.
Which? I mean, which body? Whose body?
Mine. Mucus membrane cells.
Did it hurt?
Oh, Jo, really!
I'm sorry.
Well, the point is that the maggot cells changed the internal structure of the human cells into their own nature.
Rather as a virus does.
You mean your cells turned into maggot cells?
In effect, yes.
That's what happened to those poor miners.
Correct, Jo, correct.
Well, what now?
Well, we'll just have to get a hold of one of those maggots, won't we?
Down the mine again?

No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nancy enters.

What?

Standing by, sir.
Right then, clear the area.
Right, sir.
Wait, wait, Brigadier. Give me an hour.
Okay, lads, clear the area!
Give me half an hour.
Get a move on!
At least give me a chance to talk to the wretched man.
You've exactly thirty two and a half minutes.
Right.
For over a quarter of an hour I've listened patiently to you, Doctor. Now it's my turn.
Mister Stevens, at the moment those maggots and their eggs are situated in one place where we can observe them. Now if you seal off that mine, then we shall have no way of knowing

Oh, then you don't intend to blow up the mine?
You have convinced me that you are an arrant sensation monger, a political hothead and a scientific charlatan. Giant maggots indeed!
All I'm asking for is a little more time.
Time to spread more calumnies, more lies?
Time to find out the truth. Time to find out if the waste from your product is causing these maggots to appear.
That's enough! I warn you, Doctor, if you persist in these slanders, I shall have you restrained under the Emergency Powers Act.
You have no such right.
The necessary authority was brought to me this morning.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevens uses the intercom.

Dialogue.Line: Stella? Ask Mister Elgin to bring in the man from the Ministry, will you? Do you realise what my process can mean to the economy of this country? Can you imagine any government allowing such

Dialogue.Line: Ah. come in, will you? Doctor, may I introduce you to Mister Yates?
How do you do?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: UNIT Captain Mike Yates.

Dialogue.Line: How do you do?
Come on, Doctor. Come on. How much longer? It's too late, isn't it.
In two and a half minutes, the Brigadier's going to press that button.
If he does that, it would be criminal folly.
I'm sorry, Doctor, but the Brigadier's orders and my own are quite clear.
Orders. Is nobody capable of acting on their own around here?
I'm sorry.
Right, Benton, stand by.
Right, take cover, lads. Stand by.

Dialogue.Line: No. No, you can't.
Ten, nine, eight
You must stop him!
Five, four
I can't.

Two, one, fire!

The explosion is heard here.

Perhaps it's all for the best.
The best? I think you'll find, Mister Yates, that this is the worst day's work the world has seen for many, many years.
I don't think we need detain you, Doctor.
No.
And, Doctor?
Yes?
I would advise you not to come back here. If you should be so foolish, you would be received with considerably less courtesy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves.

Dialogue.Line: And now, Mister Yates, we must make sure you are well looked after during your little stay. Elgin? Show Mister Yates to the visitor's suite, will you?
Thank you, Mister Stevens.
Do you have a case?
It's in the car.
Good, we can get it out together (Yates and Elgin leave.)
Ah, Stevens, the adrenaline flowing nicely? Living dangerously? That's how you get your kicks, like the good little Nietzschean you are, right?
I don't know what you mean.
No? Supposing this Doctor had managed to persuade them to hold up the sealing of the mine. The Brigadier is a friend of his, you know.
It would only have been temporary.
Ah. Long enough, perhaps, for them to get one of these creatures. Not safe to ask outsiders to do our work for us.
Of course. I'm sorry.
Oh, don't apologise, my little superman. Just be sure next time. The day is coming fast. D-day. Der Tag. Nothing must be allowed to stop it. Nothing.
Mike Yates, here?
Yes.
Well, why didn't you tell me?
Didn't give me much of a chance, did you?
Well, what's the idea?
Well, I'm not such a dunderhead as you all seem to think. I don't like this fellow Stevens any more than you do.
Then why did you blow up the mine.
Orders, Doctor, orders. I'm still a soldier, you know. But that doesn't stop me having an inside man to have a shuftie round.
Yes, well, I take your point, Brigadier. But, you know, there are times when I do wish that your devotion to duty was a trifle more flexible, shall we say.
I don't understand you lot. Seems to me the problem's solved. We'll see no more of those creepy-crawlies, you mark my words.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jones, Jo and the Doctor stare at the Brigadier.
The cleaning lady unlocks the door and enters with a duster, dustpan and brush. Is that all?

Dialogue.Line: Oh!
Mrs Griffiths, what on earth's the matter?
Oh, in there! Horrible, it is!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Elgin enters the pumping room and sees for himself.
A UNIT Land Rover drives over the black waste and stops by a lone sentry.

Dialogue.Line: Everything okay? Well, keep your eyes open, just in case.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton spots a maggot coming out of the ground by the sentry's boot.

Dialogue.Line: Look out, man! Get back!
Nonsense!
It is not nonsense. The pipe is full of them. They're about two feet long. They must have come up from the bottom of the mine. Everything that Doctor said is true.
I'm not disputing it, dear boy, but there's no need to get so excited about it. There's a simple remedy. Pump down more waste and flush 'em away.
That is just shoving the problem underground. We've been poisoning the mine for long enough.
Poisoning? I find your choice of words a trifle excessive.
There are three people dead, Mister Stevens.
The mine has been sealed!
Am I to understand that you propose to do nothing about this?
I see no necessity.
Then I must find somebody who will. Please unlock this door.
Come and sit down, Elgin.
Unlock the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevens presses a large red button on the mind control console. A piercing sound fills the room, and Elgin's face goes blank.

Dialogue.Line: Sit down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Elgin obeys. Stevens gets out the headset.

Dialogue.Line: Don't worry. I won't hurt you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: UNIT have retreated to the edge of the heap.

Dialogue.Line: Sir. I thought it best to back it up a bit, seeing as you said they could jump.
Yes, quite right, Benton, quite right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier looks through his binoculars. The teaming white maggots show up nicely against the black slag.

Dialogue.Line: There's another lot. They're all over the place!
Well, they're all over the place.
You mean they've tunnelled their way out?
The maggots are some sort of larvae and not the finished product. Trying to find their way to daylight.
They must be coming up some of the old shafts in the mine, breaking through the last few feet of earth.
But how did it happen?
Oil waste from Global Chemicals must have contaminated some of the maggots causing an atavistic mutation.
Giant maggots? What kind of insects are they going to turn into?
That's a very good question, Jo.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maggots are emerging near the edge of the heap. The soldiers try shooting them.

Dialogue.Line: Sir. Look.
Yes, I see him. Well, I never thought I'd fire in anger at a dratted caterpillar, but

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He does. We hear a ricochet.

Dialogue.Line: No, not a chance, Brigadier. Thick chitinous plates protecting the whole body surface. It's armour plated.
All right, we'll try AP bullets. Give him ten rounds rapid.
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The bullets still bounce off the maggot. The Brigadier uses his walkie talkie.

Dialogue.Line: Greyhound One to Greyhound Three. How's the spray working? Over.
No, it's no good, sir. They seem to thrive on it. It's the same with every pesticide we've tried.
There's only one real answer. A biological counter-strike.
With what?
Professor Jones is working on it, but he needs more living tissue.
There's any amount of it out there going begging.
No, wait. I don't like it. Nobody should have to risk infection until we know we have a cure. We want no more deaths.
What then?
Can you get me any oil waste from Global Chemicals?
Simplicity itself.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates is in another broom cupboard, stirring his tea when the phone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Yates. Oh. Lethbridge Stewart, my dear chap. What can I do for you?
Your report, Captain Yates. Have you discovered anymore about their oil formula?
No. No, everyone's being most helpful.
Can you get the Doctor a sample of the oil.
Of course not, Brigadier. If ever I want anything, there's always somebody right at my elbow to lend a hand.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A GC security guard stirs his own cup of tea.

Dialogue.Line: I see. So you've got nothing.
Let me talk to him.
Hold on a minute.
Captain Yates, the Doctor here. Now look, I'm going to have a stab at getting in there myself.
Well naturally, I have the utmost confidence in the security. In fact, they've, er, doubled it up since the problem arose. So we've no worries there.
Nobody can get in.
I see. Well, er, keep a look out for me anyway, will you?
Yes, of course. Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates puts the phone down.

Dialogue.Line: These military types. Always worrying about something, aren't they?
You've set yourself quite a task, Doctor. They're pretty efficient up there.
Yes. Yes, I know.

The guards raise the barrier for the familiar milk float, but it is a very old man with glasses and moustache driving.

Dialogue.Line: Where's the other bloke?
Oh the poor boyo is taken very sick. Something he ate, his mam said.
Who are you, then?

Me, oh, I'm his Da. I mean, they told me I was too old to take over, they did, but I've been doing this milk round, oh, fifty-three years, wet or fine, didn't I. Oh, there's life in the old dog yet. Ah, I was only saying to Rosie up at the Red Dragon. A big fine strapping girl she is

Thank you.
Yes, and you.

You know, when I first started working for UNIT, the Brigadier told me this was going to be my job. You know, holding test tubes for the Doctor and telling him how brilliant he was. Never seemed to get around to it though somehow.
A pretty dull sort of job.

Aye, so am I. Look, Jo.
Mmm hmm?
When all this business is over, I was wondering if you'd

Oh, Cliff.

I'm sorry.
All wasted.
What was that stuff?
Dried fungus. My hybrid. I'll have to do the whole lot again.
Well, no, you won't, because all you've got to do is just
No, leave it! I shudder to think what might happen.
I'm sorry.

Dialogue.Line: Cliff?
Mmm?
What you really need is a maggot, isn't it?
First things first.
Okay. Well, what shall I do?
Keep me company? Make some coffee?
Like a dutiful tea girl?
Right.
In a frilly cap and an apron?
Perfect.
Would you like a nice cup of arsenic?
Fine, fine, whatever you've got.

No?
